entry.title: Let’s Dive into Entity Framework
entry.content:
You'll need to store data at some point of your application. When you do, you'll need to use a persistence database framework. You could write it on your own or you could use an existing one. If you're a beginner developer like me, why would you bother yourself re-inventing the wheel. Just use what is best out there. The best database framework for C# is Entity Framework.


Thanks to Entity Framework, we no longer need to manage database connections, manual mapping, stored procedures and things like those. Entity Framework would take care all of them for us.


Different Approaches in Entity Framework

There are three approaches in Entity Framework.

  • Code First Approach: We create our domain classes and Entity Framework generates the data tables accordingly.
  • Database First Approach: We create our data tables and Entity Framework generates the domain classess accordingly.
  • Model First Approach: We create models and their assosications and Entity Framework generates the data tables and domain classes accordingly.

If you developed some applications using Django Framework. You'd knew about the code first approach. I'm familiar with the code first concept so I'd stick to it. If you'd like to learn more about other approaches, there are many resources online. For the rest of the post, I'll talk about the code first approach.


Create Domain Class

Let's create a simple contact management app. Let's make it console application for now. Go ahead and create the project.


Once you created the project, go ahead and and create a folder named Models. Later, add Contact.cs class to that folder. Final folder structure should be as follow:



Let's modify the Contact.cs file as follow.


As you can see, we have all the properties that we want in our database. Since we're using code first approach, Entity Framework will help us to convert these properties into database columns.


Create Entity Framework Project

I've been looking at Entity Framework codes on Github and I believe the best approach is to seperate the domain classes and Entity Framework setup than each other. That's why I'm going to create a new project just for Entity Framework setup.


Once we created our ContactManagement.EntityFramework project - which is a Class Library (.Net Core) - we need to install Entity Framework as dependency. We need to follow below steps to do so.

  • Right click on the Dependencies under the project and click on the Manage Nuget Packages.
  • Go ahead and Browse the available packages and search for Entity Framework Core.
  • Select the package with the name Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore and install the latest version.

There are two versions of Entity Framework. One is EntityFramework and the other one is EntityFrameworkCore. Since we're working on .Net Core, we installed EntityFrameworkCore. If you are working on .Net Framework than you need to install EntityFramework otherwise you'll get errors.

Let's add a new class named ContactManagementDbContext and modify it as follow.


The above code uses .UseSqlServer method. To be able to use it you have to install EntityFrameworkCore.SqlServer package through Nuget Package Manager.

We need EntityFrameworkCore.Tools package to make the migrations so go ahead and install it as well.


Once you installed the EntityFrameworkCore.Tools package, you're good to go. Let's open the package manager console and create the initial migration by typing add-migration initial. I'd like to name my first migrations as initial. You can choose whatever the name you'd like.


If you were able to add the migrations then you should update the database by typing update-database on the package manager console. If you run this code for the first time it'll create the database for you. Go ahead and check your database, you'll see the Contact table as expected.


If your connection string in ContactManagementDbContext.cs was incorrect, update-database command wouldn't run. You can always check your connection string through View > SQL Server Object Explorer.

Conclusion

We created a sample solution. We created a project for the domain class and another one for the Entity Framework setup. I'll create data services to demonstrate CRUD operations in the next posts.

You could write it on your own or you could use an existing one. If you're a beginner developer like me, why would you bother yourself re-inventing the wheel. Just use what is best out there. The best database framework for C# is Entity Framework.

entry.title: Looping in C#
entry.content:
Loops allow us to repeat same code block over and over again. It will make more sense once we learn about arrays and other data types.


The While Loop

While loop is used to repeat same code block over and over again unless a certain condition is met.


The output will be:


The value of x is equal to 1 at the beginning. The compiler will check the condition of the while loop first. X is smaller than 10 so the condition will be true. The compiler will execute the code block inside curly braces. After the execution is done, the compiler will go back to the while loop again and it will repeat the process until it meets the condition (or we specifically tell the compiler to break the loop.).


The Do-While Loop

Do-While loop is another form of a while loop. The code block will be executed in while loop only if the condition is met. Sometimes the code block will be skipped. Do-While on the otherhand is a bit different. It executes the code block first then it checks the condition. If it is met, the code block will be executed again.


Here is a basic number-guesser program using do-while loop. This can be done without using a do-while loop of course but I think it's good example.


The For Loop

entry.title: Decision making in C#
entry.content:
Every program needs to make decisions at some point. These decisions are made based on the condition of a variable.


If/Else/Else if Statement

We often use if statement (and some other form of it.) to make a decision in C#. Let's write a program that asks for the user's age. If the user is 18 or older, the user will be eligible to get a driving licence.


As you can see above, it's very easy to make a decision in C# using if statement. After if statement we have a parantheses that holds the condition variable. If the condition evaluates true then the compiler will execute the code in curly braces, if it evaluates false it will skip the code block in curly braces and move on.


Let's update the code above add the else and else if.


We don't know whether the condition will be true or false. We can make decisions for both options using else and elseif.


If there is only one statement, there is no need to use curly braces.

Relational Operators

Most of the time we make comparions to have a conditional variables. We use relational operators to compare two operands. There are 6 relational operators.

  • ==: Checks if the two operands are equal.
  • !=: Checks if the two operands are not equal.
  • <: Checks if the two left side operand is smaller than the right side operand.
  • >: Checks if the two left side operand is greater than the right side operand.
  • <=: Checks if the two left side operand is smaller than or equal to the right side operand.
  • >=: Checks if the two left side operand is greater than or equal to the right side operand.


Bools in Decision Making

It's very common to use bools in decision making. This is valid for all programming languages. Here is an example.


As you can see above, relational operators return a bool value so they can be used in a way I used above.

It's also possible to logical opposite of a bool in decision making. Using ! operator.


Logical Operators (AND and OR)

These are the logical equivalent of AND and OR operators.

  • AND Operator: If the all operands are True, the condition will be True.
  • OR Operator: If any of the operands is True, the condition will be True.


Ternary Operator

Ternary operators work on three operands unlike unary operators or binary operators. Ternary operator is also called the conditional operator and it works like if-else statement.


The way of using ternary operator is like:

Ternary operator is a one-liner so it's nice to know it but for me it reduces the readability so I wouldn't use it for most cases.


Switch Statement

The last statement in decision making I'd like to talk about is Switch Statement. Switch statement and If statement can be used interchangeably for most cases. Sometimes using one of them instead of the other can be more readable.


The output will be:

Switch statement doesn't allow logical operators as case condition. If this is the case, we could only use if statement not switch.


break should be used for every case unlike C++ and Java. Otherwise the compiler will raise an error.

Integer Division

Different Types and Casting

C# is a type-safe language. We mentioned about this before. If you want to have a math operations on two numbers, they have to be the same type. C# has a feature to make things easier for us in this case. It's called typecasting which also known as casting.


There are two types of casting.

  • Implicit Casting:C# will take care of the type conversions for us when we go from a narrower type to a wider type. This operation is also known as widening conversion. For example int data type is narrower while long data type is wider. It's all about bit size.
  • Explicit Casting: We have to tell to do the type conversion to C# specifically when we go from a wider type to a narrower type. To do that, we simply put the type we want to convert in to parantheses.
